awd_titl_txt: Formation of Molten Nanocraters on Electrodes during Charge Transfer with Conductive Droplets or Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1707137
PI: Ristenpart, William D.

When a conductive droplet or particle contacts an electrode, charge is transferred from the electrode to the droplet or particle.  Although the exact mechanism of charge transfer is not well understood, it is usually assumed that the charge transfer does not affect the electrode or the droplet or particle that contacts the electrode.  However, recent observations show that charge transfer to water droplets or other particles creates craters in the electrode's surface up to a micron wide that can be detected by electron microscopy and atomic force microscopy.  The goal of this project is to understand the mechanism of crater formation and how it affects charge transfer.  A series of experiments will test the hypothesis that Joule heating during charge transfer melts the electrode locally.  The molten metal is pushed out under pressure due to a plasma jet of the surrounding fluid.  The metal then cools and solidifies leaving behind a crater.  Understanding these and other details of charge transfer could lead to improved efficiencies in a variety of industrial electrochemical processes, including electrical de-emulsification, which is used to separate water from oil, and electrostatic precipitation, which is used to control particulate emissions.  The results of this project will be used in a general education course at UC Davis that introduces beginning students to science and engineering and is taken each year by more than 1500 students.    

The behavior of charged objects at an electrode will be characterized by a series of in situ experiments, including high speed video, high resolution chronocoulometry, and high sensitivity photon counting.  Results will be combined with post in situ characterizations of the resulting craters obtained by optical, electron, and atomic force microscopy.  Specific experiments will be aimed at directly testing the proposed mechanism of crater formation, including systematically varying the melting point temperature of the electrode, the dielectric breakdown strength of the surrounding fluid, and the radius of curvature of solid conductive particles. If corroborated, the mechanism proposed here could explain the long-standing difficulty in obtaining quantitative agreement with predicted charge transfer values, since the crater formation physically alters the electrode.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this research is to answer the question: how do conductive droplets or particles acquire electric charge when they contact an electrode? It has long been known that an electrically conductive object, such as a metal particle in air or a water droplet in oil, will acquire charge when it contacts an electrode. The exact mechanism of charge transfer, however, has remained obscure, with many measurements of the acquired charge in quantitative disagreement with theory. Previous work dating back to the 1800s has implicitly assumed that the electrode remains physically unaltered by the charging process. Our research has revealed that this assumption is incorrect: water droplets and other conducting objects create nanocraters on the electrode during charge transfer events. We used electron microscopy and atomic force microscopy to demonstrate that a typical charge transfer event for a millimeter-scale droplet creates a nano-crater on the metal electrode that is approximately 1 micron wide and 50 to 400 nanometers deep. Our systematic measurements using different types of metals corroborated the hypothesis that the charge transfer process was actually melting the metal electrodes locally to form the nanocraters, which is astonishing because the water droplets are at room temperature and the melting point of the metals is as high as 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit.  We performed detailed statistical analyses of the charge variations to demonstrate that randoms variations in the charge occur due to instabilities in the water/oil interface, and that systematic variations in the charge are associated with anomalous charge accumulation due to the ambient humidity surrounding the apparatus.  Our results provide insight on the operation and efficiency of electrostatic separators widely used in the petroleum industry to remove salty water droplets from crude oil, and also provide fundamental insight on our ability to precisely control the amount of charge acquired by objects in high voltage fields.

 


Last Modified: 06/03/2022
Modified by: William D Ristenpart

Image
  • A gold electrode (1 mm wide) that experience several hundred charge transfer events with a water droplet. Magnifications show electron microscopy and atomic force microscopy images establishing that the charge transfer events created a field of nanocraters on the gold electrode.
    Eric Elton, Ethan Rosenberg, and William Ristenpart
    Copyrighted
    William D Ristenpart
    Examples of nanocrater formation

The main goal of this research is to answer the question: how do conductive droplets or particles acquire electric charge when they contact an electrode? It has long been known that an electrically conductive object, such as a metal particle in air or a water droplet in oil, will acquire charge when it contacts an electrode. Previous work dating back to the 1800s has implicitly assumed that the electrode remains physically unaltered by the charging process.
